title: Old Judge Book - The Photographic Baseball Cards of Goodwin & Company
author: Baseball Rarities

posts.post_title: Old Judge Book - The Photographic Baseball Cards of Goodwin & Company
posts.post_content:
I have brand new copies of The Photographic Baseball Cards of Goodwin & Company (1886-1890) by Jay Miller, Joe Gonsowski & Richard Masson available for sale.

If you have interest in the Old Judge issues or other vintage cards, then this is a must for your library. This beautiful hardbound book is certainly one of the finest every produced in our hobby.

Over 450 full color pages. Nearly all known N172 Old Judge cards are pictured. Includes biographical information about each player (sample pages shown). Also has tons of info on other Old Judge issues (N167, N173, N175 etc.), how they were produced, the rarities within the set, advertising, uncut sheets, etc.

$30 delivered in the US via USPS Media Mail
$45 delivered in the US via USPS Priority Mail

PayPal FF, Venmo FF or a check is fine.

Send me a PM to order. Let me know if you have any questions.

Great price on an outstanding book...paid $50+ shipping back in the day.

Brian
I'll take one, pm sent.
Best book in the hobby and worth it's weight in gold.
I will take the $30 shipping version is a check ok? Larry

I'm sure there will be plenty of folks looking for one at that time :)
Most days the book is used, so invaluable is how I see it for serious OJ collectors or researchers.
Most days the book is used, so invaluable is how I see it for serious OJ collectors or researchers and those starting out with OJ interest.

If this book isn't in your library, then your library is incomplete......

[quote name="gnaz01" post=2365662]If this book isn't in your library, then your library is incomplete......[/QUOTE]

It's obviously a great reference.  It's also a great read on it's own for both the cards and the players.

...and it's an interesting coffee table book that many visitors have thumbed through and found interesting, even people who have no idea about baseball cards (which is most people who find themselves in my living room).

My personal want-list for A/G is 15-16 cards and I'm 2/3rd the way there.  Because of that, it's value as a reference for me is minimal, but I can't imagine getting rid of it because of it's all-around information value.
